title: Assessment and Treatment of Impaired Speech Motor Control in Children with Downs Syndrome
abstractText:
This project will make innovative use of electropalatography (EPG) to investigate speech errors in children with Down‘s syndrome. 

Speech and language are usually slow to develop in Down‘s syndrome and are typically more delayed than would be expected on the basis of level of cognitive impairment. Intelligibility is often a major problem for many children. Communication difficulties can make friendship formation difficult and impede both educational progress and social inclusion; overall quality of life may also be adversely affected. 

EPG is a technique based on a customised dental palate with 62 tiny implanted electrodes. These record the timing and location of tongue contact with the roof of the mouth during speech. This information is displayed ‘live‘ on a computer screen, allowing the child to ‘see’ where his or her tongue is when trying to say a given word and to correct any errors being made. 

This research aims to pinpoint the precise nature of differences in speech in children with Down’s syndrome and will evaluate the potential role of EPG-based therapy in reducing their articulation difficulties. Findings will be relevant to speech and language therapy provision, as well as contributing more generally to theories of speech-motor planning.
